maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the SMB server configuration.
The `Get-SmbServerConfiguration` cmdlet retrieves the Server Message Block (SMB) server configuration.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession)or Get-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/get-cimsession)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet isn't run.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession)or Get-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/get-cimsession)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet isn't run.
The MSFT_SmbServerConfiguration object represents the configuration of the SMB server.

command:example.maml:title: ----------- Example 1: Get SMB server configuration -----------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-SmbServerConfiguration
AnnounceComment : AnnounceServer : False AsynchronousCredits : 512 AuditSmb1Access : False AutoDisconnectTimeout : 15 AutoShareServer : True AutoShareWorkstation : True CachedOpenLimit : 10 DisableSmbEncryptionOnSecureConnection : True DurableHandleV2TimeoutInSeconds : 180 EnableAuthenticateUserSharing : False EnableDownlevelTimewarp : False EnableForcedLogoff : True EnableLeasing : True EnableMultiChannel : True EnableOplocks : True EnableSecuritySignature : False EnableSMB1Protocol : False EnableSMB2Protocol : True EnableStrictNameChecking : True EncryptData : False IrpStackSize : 15 KeepAliveTime : 2 MaxChannelPerSession : 32 MaxMpxCount : 50 MaxSessionPerConnection : 16384 MaxThreadsPerQueue : 20 MaxWorkItems : 1 NullSessionPipes : NullSessionShares : OplockBreakWait : 35 PendingClientTimeoutInSeconds : 120 RejectUnencryptedAccess : True RequireSecuritySignature : False ServerHidden : True Smb2CreditsMax : 8192 Smb2CreditsMin : 512 SmbServerNameHardeningLevel : 0 TreatHostAsStableStorage : False ValidateAliasNotCircular : True ValidateShareScope : True ValidateShareScopeNotAliased : True ValidateTargetName : True RestrictNamedpipeAccessViaQuic : True EnableSMBQUIC : True EncryptionCiphers : AES_128_GCM, AES_128_CCM, AES_256_GCM, AES_256_CCM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves the SMB server configuration.

maml:description.maml:para: Allow access to a computer or set of computers for SMB over QUIC's client access control feature on an SMB Server.

The `Grant-SmbClientAccessToServer` cmdlet is used to allow SMB clients to access a specified server. When you run this cmdlet, it'll add a new rule to the server's firewall to allow incoming SMB traffic from the specified client IP address. If you need to revoke access to the server in the future, you can use the `Revoke-SmbClientAccessToServer` cmdlet.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession)or Get-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/get-cimsession)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Used to provide a description of the rule being added to the server's firewall when you use the `Grant-SmbClientAccessToServer` cmdlet. This can be useful if you need to keep track of which clients have been granted access to a server, or if you need to provide additional information about the rule for documentation purposes.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.

Specifies the identity of the client that is being granted access to the SMB server. This parameter takes a string value that represents the identity of the client. The format of the string value will depend on the IdentifierType parameter that you're using.
Specifies the type of identifier that you're using to identify a client. The valid values for the IdentifierType parameter are:
- SHA256
- ISSUER

If you're using the `SHA256` identifier type, you're specifying a hash value that uniquely identifies the client. If you're using the `ISSUER` identifier type, you're specifying the issuer of the client's certificate.
Specifies the input object that's used in a pipeline command.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer.
The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet isn't run.
Specifies a fully-qualified DNS name or NetBIOS name that must match the certificate's subject name or an entry in the certificate's subject alternative names.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession)or Get-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/get-cimsession)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Used to provide a description of the rule being added to the server's firewall when you use the `Grant-SmbClientAccessToServer` cmdlet. This can be useful if you need to keep track of which clients have been granted access to a server, or if you need to provide additional information about the rule for documentation purposes.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.

Specifies the identity of the client that is being granted access to the SMB server. This parameter takes a string value that represents the identity of the client. The format of the string value will depend on the IdentifierType parameter that you're using.
Specifies the type of identifier that you're using to identify a client. The valid values for the IdentifierType parameter are:
- SHA256
- ISSUER

If you're using the `SHA256` identifier type, you're specifying a hash value that uniquely identifies the client. If you're using the `ISSUER` identifier type, you're specifying the issuer of the client's certificate.

If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer.
The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet isn't run.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession)or Get-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/get-cimsession)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Used to provide a description of the rule being added to the server's firewall when you use the `Grant-SmbClientAccessToServer` cmdlet. This can be useful if you need to keep track of which clients have been granted access to a server, or if you need to provide additional information about the rule for documentation purposes.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.

Specifies the identity of the client that is being granted access to the SMB server. This parameter takes a string value that represents the identity of the client. The format of the string value will depend on the IdentifierType parameter that you're using.
Specifies the type of identifier that you're using to identify a client. The valid values for the IdentifierType parameter are:
- SHA256
- ISSUER

If you're using the `SHA256` identifier type, you're specifying a hash value that uniquely identifies the client. If you're using the `ISSUER` identifier type, you're specifying the issuer of the client's certificate.
Specifies the input object that's used in a pipeline command.
Specifies a fully-qualified DNS name or NetBIOS name that must match the certificate's subject name or an entry in the certificate's subject alternative names.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer.
The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet isn't run.

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 1: Grant SMB client access to a server --------
command:example.dev:code: $params = @{ Name = "Server01" IdentifierType = "ISSUER" Identifier = "CN=MyCertificateIssuer" Description = "Allow access from client for LabSvr" Force = $true } Grant-SmbClientAccessToServer @params

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example grants SMB client access to a server named `Server01` based on the client's certificate. The Description parameter is used to provide a description of the rule being added to the server's firewall. This command runs without prompting for confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Resets the Server Message Block (SMB) server configuration parameters to their default values.

The `Reset-SmbServerConfiguration` cmdlet resets SMB server configuration parameters to their default values. For more information on SMB server and protocol specifications, see Overview of file sharing using the SMB 3 protocol in Windows Server (/windows-server/storage/file-server/file-server-smb-overview)and [MS-SMB2]:Server Message Block (SMB) Protocol Versions 2 and 3 (/openspecs/windows_protocols/ms-smb2/5606ad47-5ee0-437a-817e-70c366052962).
Resets all the SMB server configuration parameters to their default values.
Resets the SMB server announce comment to its default value.
Resets the SMB server announce server to its default value.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.
Resets the asynchronous credits to its default value.
Resets the SMB over QUIC client access control audit events to its default value.
> [!NOTE] > Devices running Windows 11 version 22H2 and earlier may not have access to this parameter.
Resets auditing of the clients attempts to connect without encryption to the server to its default value.
Resets auditing of SMB clients that don't support signing to its default value.
Resets whether to audit insecure guest logon attempts to its default value.
Resets the auditing of SMB version 1 protocol behavior to its default value.
Resets the automatic sharing behavior for default server shares to its default value.
Resets the automatic sharing behavior for default workstation shares to its default value.
Resets the cache open file limit to its default value.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession)or Get-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/get-cimsession)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Resets the SMB compression behavior to its default value.
Resets the disable SMB encryption on secure connection behavior to its default value.
Resets the durable handle v2 time-out period value to its default value.
Resets the directory handle leasing on the server to its default value.
Resets the down-level timewarp support behavior to its default value.
Resets the enable leasing behavior to its default value.
Resets mailslots to its default value.
Beginning with Windows Server 2025 and Windows 11 Insider Preview Build 25314, remote mailslots are disabled by default.

To learn more about remote mailslot deprecation, see [Features removed or no longer developed starting with Windows Server 2025](/windows-server/get-started/removed-deprecated-features-windows-server-2025).
Resets the enable multi-channel behavior to its default value.
Resets the opportunistic locks behavior to its default value.
Resets the SMB2 protocol to its default value.
Resets the SMB over QUIC protocol to its default value.
Resets the strict name checking on incoming connections behavior to its default value.
Resets the session encryption behavior to its default value.
Resets the encryption ciphers used by the SMB client to its default value and order.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Resets the IRP stack size default to its default value.
Resets the keep alive time to its default value.
Resets the maximum channels per session to its default value.
Resets the maximum MPX count for SMB1 to its default value.
Resets the maximum sessions per connection to its default value.
Resets the maximum threads per queue to its default value.
Resets the maximum SMB1 work items to its default value.
Resets the null session pipes to its default value.
Resets how long the create caller waits for an opportunistic lock break to its default value.
Resets the pending client time-out period to its default value.
Resets the unencrypted access behavior to its default value.
Resets the SMB server request compression value to its default value.
Resets the named pipes behavior when using SMB over QUIC to its default value.
Resets whether the server announces itself to its default value.
Resets the maximum SMB2 credits to its default value.
Resets the minimum SMB2 credits to its default value.
Resets the maximum version of the SMB protocol to its default value.
Resets the minimum version of the SMB protocol to its default value.
Resets the SMB Service name hardening level to its default value.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Resets whether the host is treated as the stable storage to its default value.
Resets whether the aliases that aren't circular are validated to its default value.
Resets whether the existence of share scopes is checked during share creation to its default value.
Resets whether the share scope being aliased is validated to its default value.
Resets whether the target name is validated to its default value.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet isn't run.

command:example.maml:title: ------- Example 1: Reset the unencrypted access behavior -------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This commands resets only the unencrypted access behavior to its default value without user confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the Server Message Block (SMB) server configuration.

The `Set-SmbServerConfiguration` cmdlet sets the Server Message Block (SMB) Service configuration. For more information on SMB server and protocol specifications, see Overview of file sharing using the SMB 3 protocol in Windows Server (/windows-server/storage/file-server/file-server-smb-overview)and [[MS-SMB2]:Server Message Block (SMB) Protocol Versions 2 and 3](/openspecs/windows_protocols/ms-smb2/5606ad47-5ee0-437a-817e-70c366052962).
Specifies the announce comment string.
Indicates that this server announces itself by using browser announcements.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.
Specifies the asynchronous credits.

Enables SMB over QUIC client access control audit events. There are three possible events: access allowed, access denied, and error. The access allowed and access denied events list properties of the client certificate chain and any allow and deny access control entries that apply to the client certificates.
Enables auditing of SMB clients that don't support encryption. Clients that connect and don't list SMB encryption in their supported capabilities will be recorded in the Windows event log.
Enables auditing of the clients attempts to connect without signing to the server. The server logs an audit event when a client attempts to connect to the server without using message signing.
Specifies whether to audit insecure guest logon attempts. When enabled insecure guest logons will appear in Windows Event Viewer.
Enables the auditing of SMB version 1 protocol behavior.
Specifies the v1 auto disconnect time-out period, in minutes.
Specifies the v2 auto disconnect time-out period, in seconds.
Indicates that the default server shares are shared out.
Indicates whether the default workstation shares are shared out.
Specifies the maximum number of cached open files.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession)or Get-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/get-cimsession)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Indicates that the SMB server should never compress files even if client or application requested it.

Specifies that SMB encryption will also be used if configured on the SMB server. By default, QUIC encryption only is used in order to avoid double encryption affecting performance unnecessarily. If a client requires SMB encryption using `Set-SmbClientConfiguration -ForceSMBEncryptionOverQuic $true` then the DisableSmbEncryptionOnSecureConnection value is ignored and SMB encryption occurs.
Specifies the durable handle v2 time-out period, in seconds.
Indicates whether authenticate user sharing is enabled.

Enables directory handle leasing on the server. When directory handle leasing is enabled, the server can cache directory handles for a longer period of time, which can improve performance for certain workloads. This can be particularly useful in scenarios where there are a large number of directory operations being performed on the server.
Indicates whether down-level timewarp support is disabled.
Indicates whether forced logoff is enabled.
Indicates whether leasing is disabled.

Specifies whether to enable mailslots. If this parameter is specified, mailslots will be enabled. Beginning with Windows Server 2025 and Windows 11 Insider Preview Build 25314, remote mailslots are disabled by default.

To learn more about remote mailslot deprecation, see [Features removed or no longer developed starting with Windows Server 2025](/windows-server/get-started/removed-deprecated-features-windows-server-2025).
Indicates whether multi-channel is disabled.
Indicates whether the opportunistic locks are enabled.
Indicates whether the security signature is enabled.
Indicates whether the SMB1 protocol is enabled.
Indicates whether the SMB2 protocol is enabled.
Indicates whether the SMB over QUIC protocol is enabled.
Indicates whether the server should perform strict name checking on incoming connects.
Indicates whether the sessions established on this server are encrypted.
Specifies the encryption ciphers used by the SMB server and the preferred order.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the length of time in milliseconds that the server should delay before responding to an authentication request that has been deemed invalid, such as an incorrect user name or password.
Specifies the default IRP stack size.
Specifies the keep alive time.
Specifies the maximum channels per session.
Specifies the maximum MPX count for SMB1.
Specifies the maximum sessions per connection.
Specifies the maximum threads per queue.
Specifies the maximum SMB1 work items.
Specifies the null session pipes.
Specifies the null session shares.
Specifies how long the create caller waits for an opportunistic lock break.
Specifies the pending client time-out period, in seconds.
Indicates whether the client that doesn't support encryption is denied access if it attempts to connect to an encrypted share.
Indicates if SMB server should always request compression even if client or application didn't specify it.
Indicates whether the security signature is required.
Specifies that named pipes are allowed when using SMB over QUIC. A value of `$true` prevents use of named pipes and is the default.
Indicates whether the server announces itself.
Specifies the maximum SMB2 credits.
Specifies the minimum SMB2 credits.
This parameter specifies the maximum version of the SMB protocol to be used. Acceptable values are:
- None - There is no maximum protocol version specified, the server can use any supported version.
- SMB202 - SMB 2.0.2 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB210 - SMB 2.1.0 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB300 - SMB 3.0.0 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB302 - SMB 3.0.2 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB311 - SMB 3.1.1 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
This parameter specifies the minimum version of the SMB protocol to be used. Acceptable values are:
- None - There is no minimum protocol version specified, the server can use any supported version.
- SMB202 - SMB 2.0.2 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB210 - SMB 2.1.0 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB300 - SMB 3.0.0 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB302 - SMB 3.0.2 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB311 - SMB 3.1.1 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server

Controls the level of validation that a server performs on the service principal name (SPN) that is provided by the client device when the client establishes a session using Server Message Block (SMB). The acceptable values are:
- `0`: Don't enforce SPN check.
- `1`: Allow clients who didn't provide the target, but fail those who do provide the target and it
doesn't match. - `2`: Only allow clients who supply matching targets.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer.
The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Indicates whether the host is treated as the stable storage.
Indicates whether the aliases that aren't circular are validated.
Indicates that the existence of share scopes is checked during share creation.
Indicates whether the share scope being aliased is validated.
Indicates whether the target name is validated.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet isn't run.
Specifies the announce comment string.
Indicates that this server announces itself by using browser announcements.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.
Specifies the asynchronous credits.

Enables SMB over QUIC client access control audit events. There are three possible events: access allowed, access denied, and error. The access allowed and access denied events list properties of the client certificate chain and any allow and deny access control entries that apply to the client certificates.
Enables auditing of SMB clients that don't support encryption. Clients that connect and don't list SMB encryption in their supported capabilities will be recorded in the Windows event log.
Enables auditing of the clients attempts to connect without signing to the server. The server logs an audit event when a client attempts to connect to the server without using message signing.
Specifies whether to audit insecure guest logon attempts. When enabled insecure guest logons will appear in Windows Event Viewer.
Enables the auditing of SMB version 1 protocol behavior.
Specifies the v1 auto disconnect time-out period, in minutes.
Specifies the v2 auto disconnect time-out period, in seconds.
Indicates that the default server shares are shared out.
Indicates whether the default workstation shares are shared out.
Specifies the maximum number of cached open files.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/new-cimsession)or Get-CimSession (/powershell/module/cimcmdlets/get-cimsession)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Indicates that the SMB server should never compress files even if client or application requested it.

Specifies that SMB encryption will also be used if configured on the SMB server. By default, QUIC encryption only is used in order to avoid double encryption affecting performance unnecessarily. If a client requires SMB encryption using `Set-SmbClientConfiguration -ForceSMBEncryptionOverQuic $true` then the DisableSmbEncryptionOnSecureConnection value is ignored and SMB encryption occurs.
Specifies the durable handle v2 time-out period, in seconds.
Indicates whether authenticate user sharing is enabled.

Enables directory handle leasing on the server. When directory handle leasing is enabled, the server can cache directory handles for a longer period of time, which can improve performance for certain workloads. This can be particularly useful in scenarios where there are a large number of directory operations being performed on the server.
Indicates whether down-level timewarp support is disabled.
Indicates whether forced logoff is enabled.
Indicates whether leasing is disabled.

Specifies whether to enable mailslots. If this parameter is specified, mailslots will be enabled. Beginning with Windows Server 2025 and Windows 11 Insider Preview Build 25314, remote mailslots are disabled by default.

To learn more about remote mailslot deprecation, see [Features removed or no longer developed starting with Windows Server 2025](/windows-server/get-started/removed-deprecated-features-windows-server-2025).
Indicates whether multi-channel is disabled.
Indicates whether the opportunistic locks are enabled.
Indicates whether the security signature is enabled.
Indicates whether the SMB1 protocol is enabled.
Indicates whether the SMB2 protocol is enabled.
Indicates whether the SMB over QUIC protocol is enabled.
Indicates whether the server should perform strict name checking on incoming connects.
Indicates whether the sessions established on this server are encrypted.
Specifies the encryption ciphers used by the SMB server and the preferred order.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the length of time in milliseconds that the server should delay before responding to an authentication request that has been deemed invalid, such as an incorrect user name or password.
Specifies the default IRP stack size.
Specifies the keep alive time.
Specifies the maximum channels per session.
Specifies the maximum MPX count for SMB1.
Specifies the maximum sessions per connection.
Specifies the maximum threads per queue.
Specifies the maximum SMB1 work items.
Specifies the null session pipes.
Specifies the null session shares.
Specifies how long the create caller waits for an opportunistic lock break.
Specifies the pending client time-out period, in seconds.
Indicates whether the client that doesn't support encryption is denied access if it attempts to connect to an encrypted share.
Indicates if SMB server should always request compression even if client or application didn't specify it.
Indicates whether the security signature is required.
Specifies that named pipes are allowed when using SMB over QUIC. A value of `$true` prevents use of named pipes and is the default.
Indicates whether the server announces itself.
Specifies the maximum SMB2 credits.
Specifies the minimum SMB2 credits.
This parameter specifies the maximum version of the SMB protocol to be used. Acceptable values are:
- None - There is no maximum protocol version specified, the server can use any supported version.
- SMB202 - SMB 2.0.2 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB210 - SMB 2.1.0 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB300 - SMB 3.0.0 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB302 - SMB 3.0.2 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB311 - SMB 3.1.1 is the maximum version accepted by the SMB Server
This parameter specifies the minimum version of the SMB protocol to be used. Acceptable values are:
- None - There is no minimum protocol version specified, the server can use any supported version.
- SMB202 - SMB 2.0.2 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB210 - SMB 2.1.0 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB300 - SMB 3.0.0 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB302 - SMB 3.0.2 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server
- SMB311 - SMB 3.1.1 is the minimum version accepted by the SMB Server

Controls the level of validation that a server performs on the service principal name (SPN) that is provided by the client device when the client establishes a session using Server Message Block (SMB). The acceptable values are:
- `0`: Don't enforce SPN check.
- `1`: Allow clients who didn't provide the target, but fail those who do provide the target and it
doesn't match. - `2`: Only allow clients who supply matching targets.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer.
The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Indicates whether the host is treated as the stable storage.
Indicates whether the aliases that aren't circular are validated.
Indicates that the existence of share scopes is checked during share creation.
Indicates whether the share scope being aliased is validated.
Indicates whether the target name is validated.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet isn't run.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 1: Set the SMB Service configuration ---------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the SMB Service configuration without user confirmation.

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 2: Turn on SMB signing and encryption --------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command turns on SMB signing and encryption without user confirmation. This example uses splatting to pass parameter values from the `$Parameters` variable to the command. Learn more about Splatting (/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_splatting).

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Turn off the default server and workstations shares

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command turns off the default server and workstations shares without user confirmation.
This command turns off server announcements without user confirmation.
This command disables SMB1 on the SMB server without user confirmation.
This command specifies the encryption ciphers used by the SMB client, and the preferred order without user confirmation.
